Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RUI: Ecological and evolutionary responses to environmental change in Sierra Nevada populations of a montane willow beetle
Award.AbstractNarration:
Organisms in nature live in populations that may remain stable, grow, fluctuate in size, or go extinct. The physical environment, the presence of natural enemies, the genetic properties of a population and the abilities of individuals to adapt to the environment all influence population size and persistence. As ecosystems experience rapid climate change, it is imperative to understand how environmental and genetic variation affects the persistence of vulnerable populations. To focus on this critical problem, populations of a native willow beetle experiencing extreme climatic conditions in the Sierra Nevada Mountains of California will be investigated. Populations studied for over a decade will be characterized using markers of genetic variation and environmental adaptation. Changes in population size will be related to these markers, to local topography, and to climatic conditions assessed by continuously recording weather loggers. Historical samples from these populations, some of which are now extinct, will be included in this analysis, offering a rare opportunity to analyze changes in populations for which the past environment is characterized. Experiments quantifying reproduction, larval survival, and adult over-wintering survival will assess potential mechanisms contributing to population persistence for beetles of differing genetic and environmental backgrounds.

Findings will provide unique insights into the ability of organisms to cope with and adapt to a rapidly changing environment, and will enhance understanding of the effects of genetic and environmental variation on ecological interactions among species. This project continues a unique, long-term population and climate dataset, and will thus provide a substantive contribution to knowledge of the effects of global climate change on natural systems. Finally, this program will support and mentor a large number of undergraduates, including groups traditionally underrepresented in environmental biology, working in the laboratory and field as a collaborative, interdisciplinary team.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This research examined evolution “in action” by exploring relationships between genetic composition of natural populations of animals and their ability to respond to environmental change. The focal study organism was the willow leaf beetle Chrysomela aeneicollis.

Relationships between climate and population dynamics- Thermal conditions in three microhabitats relevant to beetle life were captured with temperature loggers placed in host willow foliage, at base of willow plant, and in the soil, at 64 sites in the Eastern Sierra Nevada that differ in average summer temperature. Maximum beetle abundance was also measured each summer. Results show that beetle populations fluctuate with annual climate; dry winters cause populations to crash and move to high elevation (Fig 1). Soil temperatures fluctuate more in dry years than snowy ones, and this may contribute to population decline in dry years (Fig 2).

Historical context of response to climate change- Chrysomela aeneicollis populations are distributed across Western North America. The relationship between current beetle distribution and climate was used to locate past suitable beetle habitat. DNA sequences from three genes were then used to reconstruct historical migration patterns; the analysis showed that populations have been separated from each other for at least 50,000 years, well before the most recent glaciation of 20,000 years ago. Thus, Sierra beetles have been living at high elevation for many thousands of years (Fig 3).

Consequences of genetic variation across climatic gradients for beetle populations- Variation at 12 genes analyzed across the 60 km latitudinal gradient using the program 'STRUCTURE' indicates that Sierra beetles segregate into two distinct genetic types- Northern and Southern; individuals in central populations possess a mixture of southern and northern genes (Fig 4A). However, variation at a nuclear gene for an enzyme critical for converting sugar to energy, phosphoglucose isomerase (PGI), and another gene important for aerobic metabolism, mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase (COII), is significantly more divergent than for other loci. Furthermore, variation at PGI and COII is concordant along an environmental temperature gradient (Fig 4B). Variation at COII and PGI is related to two measures of beetle performance, growth rate and running speed, suggesting that these genes are under selection together (Fig 4C). Individuals with southern COII performed best after heat stress when they possessed southern PGI, while individuals with northern COII and southern PGI performed poorly. Thus, mito-nuclear interactions affect traits important for survival and reproduction. This approach was expanded to examine other metabolic genes. Single nucleotide polymorphisms were identified in regions of 30 genes from the genetically diverse BC population and subsequently examined across the latitudinal gradient. Most genes showed moderate genetic differentiation, but a few genes showed striking patterns. Genes coding for the enzymes succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) showed unusually high variation between drainages, and frequencies of SDH variants varied with elevation in BC. Variation at SDH has been shown to interact with PGI in other insects, and LDH is key for responding to exercise-induced reductions in oxygen supply. These results suggest that natural selection affects enzymes involved in energy and oxygen metabolism in Sierra willow beetles.
